column1: Olympia is the capital of the U.S. state of Washington and the county seat and largest city of Thurston County. European settlers claimed the area in 1846
column2: with the Treaty of Medicine Creek initiated in 1854
column3: and the Treaty of Olympia initiated in January 1856.Olympia was incorporated as a town on January 28
column5: and as a city in 1882. The population was 46
column7: making it the 24th largest city in the state. The city borders Lacey to the east and Tumwater to the south. Olympia is a cultural center of the southern Puget Sound region. Olympia is located 60 miles (100 km) southwest of Seattle
column8: the largest city in the state of Washington.

column1: The site of Olympia had been home to Lushootseed-speaking peoples known as the Steh-Chass (or Stehchass
column2: later part of the post-treaty Squaxin Island Tribe) for thousands of years. Other Native Americans regularly visited the head of Budd Inlet and the Steh-Chass including the other ancestor tribes of the Squaxin
column4: Puyallup
column5: Chehalis
column7: and Duwamish. The first recorded Europeans came to Olympia in 1792. Peter Puget and a crew from the British Vancouver Expedition are said to have explored the site
column8: but neither recorded any encounters with the resident Indigenous population here. In 1846
column9: Edmund Sylvester and Levi Lathrop Smith jointly claimed the land that is now downtown Olympia. In 1851
column10: the U.S. Congress established the Customs District of Puget Sound for Washington Territory and Olympia became the home of the customs house. Its population steadily expanded from Oregon Trail immigrants. In 1850
column11: the town settled on the name Olympia
column12: at the suggestion of local resident Colonel Isaac N. Ebey
column13: because of its view of the Olympic Mountains to the Northwest. The area began to be served by a small fleet of steamboats known as the Puget Sound Mosquito Fleet.

column1: Over the course of two days
column4: Governor Isaac I. Stevens negotiated the Treaty of Medicine Creek with the representatives of the Nisqually
column5: Puyallup
column7: Steh'Chass
column12: and S'Hotl-Ma-Mish tribes. Stevens' treaty included the preservation of Indigenous fishing
column14: gathering and other rights. It also included a section which
column15: at least as interpreted by United States officials
column16: required the Native American signatories to move to one of three reservations. Doing so would effectively force the Nisqually people to cede their prime farming and living space. One of the leaders of the Nisqually
column19: refused to give up ownership of this land and instead fought for his peoples' right to their territory
column20: sparking the beginning of the Puget Sound War. The war ended in the controversial execution of Leschi.

column1: The 1949 Olympia earthquake damaged many historic buildings beyond repair
column2: and they were demolished. Parts of the city also suffered damage from earthquakes in 1965 and 2001.

column3: the city has a total area of 19.68 square miles (50.97 km2)
column4: of which 17.82 sq mi (46.15 km2) are land and 1.86 sq mi (4.82 km2) are water.The city of Olympia is located at the southern end of Puget Sound on Budd Inlet. The Deschutes River estuary was dammed in 1951 to create Capitol Lake. Much of the lower area of downtown Olympia sits on reclaimed land. The cities of Lacey and Tumwater border Olympia.

column1: The region surrounding Olympia has a warm-summer Mediterranean climate (Köppen Csb)
column2: whereas the local microclimate has dry summers and cool July and August overnight lows. It is part of USDA Hardiness zone 8a
column3: with isolated pockets around Puget Sound falling under zone 8b. Most of western Washington's weather is brought in by weather systems that form near the Aleutian Islands in Alaska. It contains cold moist air
column4: which brings western Washington cold rain
column5: cloudiness
column6: and fog. November through January are Olympia's rainiest months. City streets
column7: creeks
column8: and rivers can flood during the months of November through February. The normal monthly mean temperature ranges from 38.4 °F (3.6 °C) in December to 64.1 °F (17.8 °C) in August. Seasonal snowfall for 1981–2010 averaged 10.8 inches (27.4 cm) but has historically ranged from trace amounts in 1991–92 to 81.5 in (207 cm) in 1968–69.Olympia averages 50 inches (1
column9: 270 mm) of precipitation annually and has a year-round average of 75% cloud cover. Annual precipitation has ranged from 29.92 in (760 mm) in 1952 to 66.71 in (1
column10: 694 mm) in 1950; for water year (October 1 – September 30) precipitation
column11: the range is 32.71 in (831 mm) in 2000–01 to 72.57 in (1
column12: 843 mm) in 1998–99.  With a period of record dating back to 1948
column13: extreme temperatures have ranged from −8 °F (−22 °C) on January 1
column17: 2009; the record cold daily maximum is 18 °F (−8 °C) on January 31
column21: the record warm daily minimum is 69 °F (21 °C) on July 22
column23: there are 6.3 days annually with temperatures reaching 90 °F (32 °C)
column24: 1.8 days where the temperature stays at or below freezing all day
column25: and 78 nights where the low reaches the freezing mark. The average window for freezing temperatures is October 8 through May 3

column1: Olympia has a wide array of public parks and nature conservation areas. The Woodard Bay Natural Resources Conservation Area is a 600-acre (2.4 km2) parcel that preserves more than 5 miles (8.0 km) of Puget Sound waterfront along the Woodard and Chapman Bays of the Henderson Inlet. Percival Landing Park includes 0.9 miles (1.4 km) of boardwalk along Budd Inlet
column4: and a large open space. The boardwalk leads north to an open-air amphitheater
column5: a viewing tower beside the Port of Olympia
column6: as well as the Olympia Farmers' Market. Percival Landing closed in 2010 for an extensive remodel after saltwater degradation and opened again to the public in the summer of 2011. Watershed Park is the site of the former waterworks for the city and today has a loop trail with a large second-growth forest. Other parks include Priest Point Park
column7: Burfoot Park
column11: which is home to one of Olympia's public skate parks
column13: which is nestled in a small Eastside Community
column15: which was created by the efforts of adjoining neighborhood associations with the easement of private property. The Nisqually National Wildlife Refuge is located just outside Olympia
column16: as is the Capitol State Forest.

column1: Olympia was historically dependent on artesian waters. Early settlers in Swantown and Tumwater used artesian springs for their main water supply. The artesian spring at Fourth Avenue and Main Street (now called Capitol Way) was the main community well where settlers
column2: as well as the local Steh-Chass and visiting Native Americans
column3: gathered to socialize. Settler accounts recall paying Native Americans to collect water here. The artesian well at Artesian Commons park
column4: a former parking lot
column5: is active. Another still flows at the corner of Olympia Avenue and Washington Street. A small park was constructed around another spring in the Bigelow Neighborhood. The northeast end of Capitol Lake was the location of an artesian well until the construction of a new park that included changes to the shoreline. McAllister Springs
column6: the main water source for Olympia
column7: is fed by artesian wells
column8: and the former Olympia Brewery is supplied by 26 artesian wells.

column1: Efforts to protect and preserve the free flowing artesian well on 4th Ave in downtown Olympia began in 1991 when Jim Ingersoll
column3: called on the city council to acquire the well and develop it as a community park.  Ingersoll's interest in the well started in a conversation with Dick Batdorf
column4: co-founder of Batdorf & Bronson coffee roasting.  Batdorf told Ingersoll that the secret to great coffee was great water – specifically artesian water.  Subsequently
column5: Ingersoll met at the Spar restaurant with Herb Legg and John Robinson both of whom had worked in the 1950s and 60s to protect the artesian wells in Watershed Park. Legg and Robinson worked behind the scenes to get an article published in the Olympian on February 24
column7: calling for community support of the well.  Ingersoll was flooded with phone calls offering time
column9: resources and money following the publication.  Herb Legg and friends sponsored a public meeting at the Library where more than 50 people each donated $50.  And a single $3000 donation followed the next day.

column1: With hundreds of people using the well every day
column2: community support grew to become "The Friends of Artesians"
column3: an informal organization of advocates who over the course of 20 years mapped and researched the history of artesian wells in Olympia
column4: raised money to test water quality and make improvements to the site and kept the vision of a free flowing community well alive.  In the fall of 2008
column5: The Friends announced they would stop testing the water quality after February 2009.  These actions renewed interest in protecting the well and led to the creation of H2Olympia
column7: efforts to preserve the use of artesian water at the one remaining public well has been the mission of H2Olympia: Artesian Well Advocates. In 2011
column9: 000 towards improvements of an artesian well
column10: located in a parking lot that was purchased by the city the same year. Renovations at the artesian well were completed in late 2011
column13: and a raised area to fill bottles. In spring of 2012
column14: sea-themed mosaic artwork created by community members was also installed at the site of the well.

column1: Olympia is a regional center for fine arts. A number of theatrical experiences are available with companies such as Animal Fire Theater
column4: Olympia Little Theater
column5: and Harlequin Productions at the historic State Theater. The Olympia Symphony Orchestra performs five regular season concerts at the Washington Center and two pop concerts. The Masterworks Chorale Ensemble performs four regular season concerts at the Washington Center for the Performing Arts.

column1: Visual art venues include some of the local coffeehouses
column4: and Burial Grounds in downtown. Art House Designs is an art gallery that also hosts a jazz performance space. Murals and public art installations of sculpture are prevalent in Olympia and are especially featured on the State Capitol Campus and along Percival Landing on the urban waterfront. The Washington Center for the Performing Arts also presents visual art exhibitions throughout the season in the spacious lobby areas.

column1: Notable art venues near Olympia include Art in Ecology
column2: housed in Washington Department of Ecology's 322
column4: three-story building on the campus of Saint Martin's University. Art in Ecology is a long-established art-in-the-workplace venue that has works by numerous northwest artists. Permanent installations by Alfredo Arreguin
column5: commissioned by the Washington State Arts Commission
column6: are accompanied by changing solo and group exhibitions throughout the year. Appointments to view the works are needed; tours take about an hour.

column1: The South Puget Sound Community College has a gallery in its Minnaert Center with rotating exhibitions. The Evergreen State College
column3: has a professionally curated gallery with rotating shows in the Dan Evans Library building. To the south of Olympia
column4: Monarch Contemporary Art Center and Sculpture Park offers an 80-acre sculpture garden and art gallery.

column2: the Olympia Film Society (OFS) produces a film festival and fosters film and video education in Olympia. It also shows independent

column5: OFS supports and presents a variety of cultural events
column7: an all-night horror film screening with a cult following.

column2: Olympia hosted the U.S. Olympic women's marathon trial. The winner of the event was Joan Benoit who would later win a gold medal at the first women's Olympic marathon at the 1984 Summer Olympic games in Los Angeles.

column2: the national passenger rail system provides service to Olympia-Lacey at Centennial Station. Amtrak train 11
column4: departs Olympia at 11:21am with service to Centralia; Portland; Sacramento; Emeryville
column5: California (with bus connection to San Francisco); and Los Angeles. Amtrak train 14
column7: departs Olympia at 6:22pm daily with service to Tacoma and Seattle. Amtrak Cascades trains

column4: and the surrounding area are primarily served by Intercity Transit
column5: with connections to Grays Harbor Transit
column7: Pierce Transit
column8: and Sound Transit. Intercity Transit maintains a free shuttle route called "Dash". Dash runs from the Capitol Campus to the Farmers Market at the far edge of downtown. Intercity Transit's Olympia Express provides service to Lakewood and Tacoma
column9: with connections to regional bus and commuter rail service. In 2009 Intercity Transit won an award for America's best Public Transportation System in the midsize category by the American Public Transportation Association. The fleet runs entirely on biodiesel fuel and is composed of about 20% biodiesel-electric hybrid buses.
